case_vignette: A 58-year-old white man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a painless lesion on his lower lip. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. He has worked as a fruit picker for the past 25 years. His current medications include captopril and metformin. Examination of the oral cavity shows a single ulcer near the vermillion border.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've had a painless sore on my lower lip for the last 3 months.
How old are you?
I am 58 years old.
Have you experienced any unexplained weight loss or fatigue recently?
No, I haven't experienced any unexplained weight loss or fatigue.
Do you have a history of excessive sun exposure or sunburns?
I've worked outside as a fruit picker for the last 25 years.
Have you ever been diagnosed with skin cancer before?
No, I have never been diagnosed with skin cancer before.
Are you taking any medications or supplements that may affect your immune system?
I am currently taking captopril and metformin.
Is there a history of skin cancer in your family?
I haven't mentioned anything about my family's medical history.
Apologies for the assumption. Is there a history of skin cancer in your family?
No, there is not.
**Final Diagnosis:** Squamous cell carcinoma of the lip
